title: A quick introduction to MetaboCrates
text: MetaboCrates package contains tools processing analyzing Biocrates® metabolomics data. allows users easily upload data perform automated preprocessing, including data cleaning, imputation missing values, checking comprehensiveness dataset. Additionally, offers tools quality control calculating descriptive statistics, allows users quickly save results.

title: A quick introduction to MetaboCrates
text: package can easily installed loaded environment using commands: , Biocrates® data can imported read_data() function. guide example dataset, included package, used. Class dat object data.frame raw_data. following attributes: LOD_table - LOD, LLOQ ULOQ table counts - types missing values found data counts NA_ratios_type - fractions missing values type per every metabolite NA_ratios_group - fractions missing values respect declared group levels per every metabolite metabolites - names metabolites data samples - names sample types counts group - name grouping column (appears using add_group() function) removed - names removed metabolites completed - completed data (appears imputation) cv - coefficients variation based QC sample type metabolite (appears using calculate_CV() function). Non-null attributes stage presented . Now, information missing values can displayed.  next step data preprocessing.
code: devtools::install_github("BioGenies/MetaboCrates")  library(MetaboCrates) path <- get_example_data("two_sets_example.xlsx") dat <- read_data(path)  get_info(dat) #> [1] "Data contains 13 sample types and 2 NA types." attr(dat, "LOD_table")[,1:5] #>                    plate bar code     C0     C2     C3 C3-DC (C4-OH) #> 1   LOD (calc.) 1052125775-1 [µM]     NA     NA     NA            NA #> 2   LOD (calc.) 1052125780-1 [µM] 0.7702 0.0545 0.0000        0.0206 #> 3   LOD (calc.) 1052126590-1 [µM]     NA     NA     NA            NA #> 4   LOD (calc.) 1052126601-1 [µM] 1.4720 0.0269 0.0000        0.0002 #> 5 LOD (from OP) 1052125775-1 [µM]     NA     NA     NA            NA #> 6 LOD (from OP) 1052125780-1 [µM] 1.6670 0.1333 0.1222        0.0900 #> 7 LOD (from OP) 1052126590-1 [µM]     NA     NA     NA            NA #> 8 LOD (from OP) 1052126601-1 [µM] 1.6670 0.1333 0.1222        0.0900  attr(dat, "NA_info")[["NA_ratios"]][5:10,] #> NULL attr(dat, "NA_info")[["counts"]] #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   type      n #>   <chr> <dbl> #> 1 < LOD 16240 #> 2 NA      316  attr(dat, "metabolites")[1:10] #>  [1] "C0"            "C2"            "C3"            "C3-DC (C4-OH)" #>  [5] "C3-OH"         "C3:1"          "C4"            "C4:1"          #>  [9] "C5"            "C5-DC (C6-OH)"  attr(dat, "samples")[1:5,] #> # A tibble: 5 × 2 #>   `sample type` count #>   <chr>         <int> #> 1 Blank             1 #> 2 QC Level 1        2 #> 3 QC Level 2        6 #> 4 QC Level 3        2 #> 5 Sample          159 attr(dat, "NA_info")[["counts"]] #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   type      n #>   <chr> <dbl> #> 1 < LOD 16240 #> 2 NA      316  plot_mv_types(dat)

title: A quick introduction to MetaboCrates
text: First, let’s specify grouping column, can’t contain missing values (NA’s). Although step isn’t necessary, tools require grouped data. grouping,NA_info attribute contains missing values ratios group levels metabolite. Moreover, grouping column name added group attribute. , information grouped data displayed.  Next, let’s focus clearance data. grouped data passed, function returns names metabolites given threshold missing values. grouping column specified, returns metabolites threshold exceeded group level. examples threshold 20%. Aside removing metabolites, data imputation can also performed, using complete_data() function. completes missing values related limits quantification detection. Imputation missing value type can performed one five ways: NULL - skipping imputation halfmin - half minimum observed value halflimit - half detection limit random - random number smaller limit detection bigger minimum observed value limit - detection limit. Completed dataset stored completed attribute. Getting metabolites remove can also based coefficient variation value. following example, metabolites CV value greater 0.8 returned. remove metabolites data, function can used. Instead actually removing data, function adds provided metabolites removed attribute. Additionally, type removal can specified - either LOD, QC QC_man. , data LOD ratios without removed metabolites can displayed. , first 10 rows tibbles chosen columns first visible. two options restoring metabolites - either specific ones can selected metabolites specified type can restored.
code: grouped_dat <- add_group(dat, "submission name") attr(grouped_dat, "NA_info")[["NA_ratios"]][5:10,] #> NULL  attr(grouped_dat, "group") #> [1] "submission name" get_info(grouped_dat) #> [1] "Data contains 13 sample types and 2 NA types.\nGroupping by: \"submission name\" (2 levels)."  plot_groups(grouped_dat) get_LOD_to_remove(dat, 0.2)[1:10] #> No group to use! It will be ignored. #>             If you want to use group provide it with add_group function first. #>  [1] "AbsAcid"  "Ac-Orn"   "Anserine" "BABA"     "C10:1"    "C10:2"    #>  [7] "C12-DC"   "C12:1"    "C14"      "C14:1-OH"  get_LOD_to_remove(grouped_dat, 0.2)[1:10] #>  [1] "AbsAcid"  "Ac-Orn"   "Anserine" "C10:1"    "C10:2"    "C12-DC"   #>  [7] "C12:1"    "C14"      "C14:2"    "C14:2-OH" comp_dat <- complete_data(grouped_dat, LOD_method = "limit") #> Completing 16240 < LOD values... #> No < LLOQ values found. #> No > ULOQ values found. comp_dat <- calculate_CV(comp_dat)  get_CV_to_remove(comp_dat, 0.8)[1:10] #>  [1] "C16:2"             "C18:2"             "C3:1"              #>  [4] "C4:1"              "C5-OH (C3-DC-M)"   "C7-DC"             #>  [7] "Cer d18:1/18:0-OH" "Cer d18:1/26:1"    "Cer d18:2/18:0"    #> [10] "Cer d18:2/18:1" dat_with_metabo_removed <- remove_metabolites(comp_dat, c("C8", "C10"), "LOD") dat_with_metabo_removed <- remove_metabolites(dat_with_metabo_removed, c("C8", "C12:1"), "QC_man")  attr(dat_with_metabo_removed, "removed") #> $LOD #> [1] "C8"  "C10" #>  #> $QC #> NULL #>  #> $QC_man #> [1] "C8"    "C12:1" show_data(dat_with_metabo_removed)[1:5, c(1:3, 19:21)] #>                plate bar code sample bar code sample type    C2     C3 #> 1 1052126590-1 | 1052126601-1        10000001       Blank    NA     NA #> 2 1052125775-1 | 1052125780-1      1020527268  QC Level 1 1.999 0.7022 #> 3 1052126590-1 | 1052126601-1      1020527268  QC Level 1 2.083 0.7166 #> 4 1052125775-1 | 1052125780-1      1020527272  QC Level 2 3.689  1.461 #> 5 1052125775-1 | 1052125780-1      1020527272  QC Level 2 3.088  1.369 #>   C3-DC (C4-OH) #> 1            NA #> 2         < LOD #> 3        0.0134 #> 4        0.0346 #> 5        0.0344  show_ratios(dat_with_metabo_removed)[7:12,] #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   metabolite NA_frac #>   <chr>        <dbl> #> 1 ADMA         0     #> 2 AbsAcid      1     #> 3 Ac-Orn       1     #> 4 AconAcid     0     #> 5 Ala          0     #> 6 Anserine     0.943 attr(unremove_metabolites(dat_with_metabo_removed, "C8"), "removed") #> $LOD #> [1] "C10" #>  #> $QC #> NULL #>  #> $QC_man #> [1] "C12:1"  attr(unremove_all(dat_with_metabo_removed, "QC_man"), "removed") #> $LOD #> [1] "C8"  "C10" #>  #> $QC #> NULL #>  #> $QC_man #> NULL

title: A quick introduction to MetaboCrates
text: First, let’s create barplots missing values percents. function takes argument type, can set joined (default) get plot missing values metabolite else NA_type group add division missing values types levels grouping column respectively. Next function creates heatmap, shows value missing sample metabolite. , cropped plot presented, showing metabolites 5th 10th first 50 samples. Moreover, heatmap correlations metabolites can created, using function. Aside plots corresponding metabolites, MetaboCrates package also provides tools visualizations related specific metabolite. Next three functions create histogram, boxplot Q-Q plot, based values measured one metabolite. Moreover, package allows creating density plot specific metabolite, dash line representing limit detection retrieved LOD table. Next, one can create beeswarm plot specified metabolite, visualizing distribution metabolite values across different plate bar codes. Another function creates scatter plot two metabolites values pairs. also incorporates information plate bar code limit detection values. Next tool allows creating barplot, showing minimum number greatest variances explained principal component Principal Component Analysis, cumulative sum less equal given threshold. plot also includes line graph representing cumulative variance explained components. , threshold set 80%.  Principal Component Analysis tool create_pca_plot() function, mentioned Quality control section. argument type can set group, creates PCA plot respect specified group levels.
code: library(ggplot2)  plot_NA_percent(grouped_dat) +   xlim(attr(grouped_dat, "metabolites")[5:10]) #> NULL  plot_NA_percent(grouped_dat, type = "NA_type") +   xlim(attr(grouped_dat, "metabolites")[5:10]) #> NULL  plot_NA_percent(grouped_dat, type = "group") +   xlim(attr(grouped_dat, "metabolites")[5:10]) #> NULL # plot_heatmap(dat) + #   xlim(c(0, 50)) + #   ylim(attr(grouped_dat, "metabolites")[5:10]) create_correlations_heatmap(comp_dat) +   xlim(attr(comp_dat, "metabolites")[5:10]) +   ylim(attr(comp_dat, "metabolites")[5:10]) #> NULL create_plot_of_2_metabolites(comp_dat, "C0", "C8") #> Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_interactive_point()`). pca_variance(comp_dat, 0.8) create_PCA_plot(comp_dat, type = "group") #> Joining with `by = join_by(tmp_id)` #> Too few points to calculate an ellipse #> Too few points to calculate an ellipse #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_path()`).

what: Processing and Analysis of Biocrates® Metabolomics Data
title: Processing and Analysis of Biocrates® Metabolomics Data
text: MetaboCrates designed early analysis data obtained targeted metabolomics, e.g., Biocrates® kits. simplifies streamlines data processing workflow, allowing efficiently analyze metabolite data. ’s brief overview key features:

title: Processing and Analysis of Biocrates® Metabolomics Data
text: 1. Data Import: Easily import metabolomics data generated Biocrates® platforms. 2. Preprocessing: Perform data preprocessing tasks metabolites selection <LOD imputation. Automatically identify remove metabolites high Limit Detection (LOD) proportion. Enhance accuracy data eliminating unreliable measurements. Complete missing data points metabolites based LOD values. Ensure dataset comprehensive suitable analysis. 3. Quality Control: Quality control checks data. 4. Analysis: Calculate descriptive statistics. 5. Save work: Save progress, allowing resume analysis later time. Track manage multiple projects effortlessly. Easily share findings colleagues collaborators.

text: dat raw_data object, output read_data() function. data completed, example using complete_data() function. metabolite name metabolite interest. type type plot. Can either "histogram" (default), "density", "beeswarm". bins number bins histogram plot; 30 specified. histogram_type "' (default), histogram displays values imputation. "imputed", shows values imputed. interactive logical. TRUE (default), ggiraph interactive plot returned; otherwise, standard ggplot object produced.

text: dat raw_data object, output read_data(), group specified using add_group() function. threshold minimum ratio metabolite missing values one group level metabolite included diagram, given decimal.

title: Venn diagram for group levels — create_venn_diagram
code: path <- get_example_data("small_biocrates_example.xls") dat <- read_data(path) dat <- add_group(dat, "group") create_venn_diagram(dat, 0.1) #> Warning: Although not display in plot, outside elements are still count in percentages. #> Scale for fill is already present. #> Adding another scale for fill, which will replace the existing scale.

what: Plot of variance explained by principal components — pca_variance
title: Plot of variance explained by principal components — pca_variance
text: pca_variance() creates barplot showing variance explained principal component Principal Component Analysis (PCA). includes components cumulative variance explained specified threshold, well first component cumulative variance exceeds threshold (specified maximum number, given). Optionally, line representing cumulative variance explained can included.

title: Plot of variance explained by principal components — pca_variance
code: pca_variance(   dat,   threshold,   type = "sample_type",   max_num = NULL,   cumulative = TRUE )

title: Plot of variance explained by principal components — pca_variance
text: dat raw_data object, output read_data() function. data completed, example using complete_data() function. threshold decimal indicating maximum cumulative variance include plot. type character specifying rows consider. default "sample_type", uses rows. set "group", observations type "sample" included. max_num optional integer indicating maximum number components display. cumulative logical. TRUE, line representing cumulative variance shown plot.

title: Plot of variance explained by principal components — pca_variance
code: path <- get_example_data("small_biocrates_example.xls") dat <- read_data(path) dat <- complete_data(dat, "limit", "limit", "limit") #> Completing 109 < LOD values... #> Completing 6 < LLOQ values... #> Completing 9 < ULOQ values... pca_variance(dat, 0.8, max_num = 5)

text: plot_NA_percent() creates barplot showing proportion missing values metabolite.  Optionally, every metabolite, can include division type missing values display proportion missing values group level.

title: Barplot of missing values proportion in each metabolite — plot_NA_percent
Barplot of missing values proportion in each metabolite — plot_NA_percent
text: dat raw_data object. Output read_data() function. type character string indicating type plot return. can either "joint", "NA_type" "group". Default type "joint", creates plot missing values percents metabolite. "NA_type" additionally splits missing values type, "group" includes ratios every group level. interactive logical. TRUE (default), ggiraph interactive plot returned; otherwise, standard ggplot object produced.

title: Barplot of missing values proportion in each metabolite — plot_NA_percent
code: path <- get_example_data("small_biocrates_example.xls") dat <- read_data(path) print(plot_NA_percent(dat)) print(plot_NA_percent(dat, "NA_type")) dat <- add_group(dat, "group") print(plot_NA_percent(dat, "group"))

title: raw_data class — raw_data
raw_data class — raw_data
text: metabolomics_matrix data.frame, matrix containing biocrates data LOD_table list containing two elements: table: LOD table limits detection / quantification, types: character vector types values, example calc. meaning calculated samples op, received operator. metabolites character, vector metabolites names contained data. group NULL indicating grouping vector character names group columns. Default NULL. code throw error case : column name contained dataset, NA's grouping column, group less 2 observations.

title: raw_data class — raw_data
text: raw_data object metabolomics matrix following attributes: LOD_table NA_info: list related missing values data. contains NA_ratios: fractions missing values per every metabolite. group parameter (see ) provided counts: table types missing values counts (related "sample" type samples). metabolites samples: data.frame containing names samples types counts group : character name group table removed: list removed metabolites plate bar code: measurement two plate bar codes depending method used
